Award.AwardTitle: Ion dynamics and charge transport in ultrathin films of polymerized ionic liquids
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The rising energy needs of the modern society continue to provide a significant impetus for extensive research and development in energy storage devices. Polymer electrolytes play a key role in these devices. This project will employ specialized electrical experiments to gain deeper understanding of the impact of the confinement of the molecules within extrememly thin films and their interactions with surfaces on their electrical and mechanical properties. This fundamental understanding will be useful in guiding the design of novel functional polymer electrolytes with desirable properties for sustainable technologies, including polymerized ionic liquids for portable batteries, solar cells, fuel cells, actuators, field-effect transistors, and electrochromic devices. The information regarding the interplay between molecular structure, polymer/substrate interactions, ion transport and dynamics in thin films of polymerized ionic liquids gained from this work will be beneficial not only within the field of ionic liquids but also to the polymer science and engineering scientific communities. An important component of this project also involves several integrated educational activities. The project will contribute to training and education of specialists in polymer nanotechnology and materials science through active involvement of graduate and undergraduate students in this research. This integrated research/educational program also emphasizes work with underrepresented groups and outreach to K-12 students.



TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Polymerized ionic liquids are a novel class of functional polymers that combine the unique physicochemical properties of molecular ionic liquids (e.g. wide electrochemical windows, negligible vapor pressures, and ionic conduction) with the outstanding mechanical characteristics of polymers. These materials are promising for a variety of applications including dye-sensitized solar cells, portable batteries, actuators, field-effect transistors and electrochromic devices. Many of these technologies involve the use of polymerized ionic liquids confined in one dimension as thin films. However, fundamental understanding of the impact of one-dimensional nanoscale confinement on ion transport and dynamics in polymerized ionic liquids is still very limited. The main goal of this research is to unravel the mechanisms controlling charge transport and ion dynamics in ultrathin films of polymerized ionic liquids. The project will focus on: (i) investigating the impact of film thickness on ion conduction and dynamics in polymerized ionic liquids, (ii) unraveling the role of the polymer/substrate interactions on ion transport and dynamics, and (iii) investigating the role of chemical composition/structure on ion dynamics and charge transport in thin films of polymerized ionic liquids. The research will primarialy utilize broadband dielectric spectroscopy measurements of thin polymer films using a recently developed electrode configuration featuring silica nanostructures and an air gap. The detailed fundamental understanding of the impact of one-dimensional confinement on ion transport and dynamics gained in these studies will provide a firm scientific basis for design of more efficient polymer electrolytes suitable for potential use in electrochemical power sources and devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:This project focused on establishing fundamental understanding how the physical properties of a new class of polymer electrolytes called polymerized ionic liquids are influenced upon geometric restrictions to dimensions in the order of a few billionths of a meter. It is widely expected that many materials undergo rather drastic changes under such conditions. Therefore, if polymerized ionic liquids are to be rationally employed as next generation electrolytes for energy applications such as rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors, their behavior at interfaces and under geometric restrictions must be understood. Prior to this project, there was no establish experimental method to measure the important characteristics of ionic polymers under such conditions without altering and degrading the material under study. However, this situation has drastically changed. Using a new type of electrical contact comprising of sand pillars with dimensions of the order of a few thousandths of the diameter of human hair, it was demonstrated that such experiments are now possible. These intricate experiments revealed several details concerning the interaction of the constituents of polymerized ionic liquids at interfaces and under extreme confinement. The key results of this project deepen our understanding of the impact of nanoscale confinement and polymer/surface interactions on charge transport and ion dynamics in thin films of polymerized ionic liquids. This knowledge is necessary for deliberate design of novel functional polymer electrolytes with desirable properties for sustainable technologies, including polymerized ionic liquids for portable batteries, solar cells, fuel cells, actuators, field-effect transistors, and electrochromic devices. The information regarding the interplay between molecular structure, polymer/substrate interactions, ion transport and dynamics in thin films of polymerized ionic liquids gained from this work will be beneficial not only to the field of ionic liquids but also to the polymer science and engineering scientific communities.

Broader Impacts:The results from this research project will impact various fields of science and engineering and help lead to rational design and synthesis of novel functional materials for current and future technological applications. The results of the project have been broadly disseminated through peer reviewed publications and active participation in international and national meetings. This project also focused on expanding access to and provide hands-on training to high school, undergraduate, and graduate students who will become future scientists and engineers. Supported by this project, more than ten high school students participated in making nylon (synthetic polymer) as part of their introductory training on polymers within the framework of the High School Introduction to Engineering Systems for Twelfth Graders (HITES12). The grant also supported the training of seven undergraduate research students, especially during the summers of 2016 through 2018. Of the seven students, Zachariah Vicars, Taylor Spivey, and Alexandre Horton have since moved on to top chemical engineering graduate programs in the country. In addition, two further former undergraduate researchers supported by the grant, Konstantin Sedov and Lauren Foote have joined the Eastman Chemical Company as engineers. The rest of the undergraduate students are yet to graduate. Furthermore, one of the graduate research students supported by this grant, Maximilian Heres graduated with a PhD in chemical engineering in Summer 2018 and has since joined Local Motors company as a lead engineer. Another graduate student who was partially supported by the grant, Tyler Cosby, is scheduled to defend his doctoral dissertation in Fall 2018 and has accepted a research position at the US Naval Academy. Lastly, the final year of this grant involved training and mentoring of a new postdoctoral researcher. Thus, the project successfully supported the training of several students who will contribute to the benefit of the society, in line with the mandate and vision of the National Science Foundation.

 


Last Modified: 10/04/2018
Modified by: Joshua R Sangoro
